citation.article-title: Marinococcus gen. nov., a new genus for motile cocci with meso-diaminopimelic acid in the cell wall; and Marinococcus albus sp. nov. and Marinococcus halophilus (Novitsky and Kushner) comb. nov.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Marinococcus gen. nov.
Marinococcus (Ma.ri.no.coccus. Gr. n. marino, marine; Gr. n. coccus, a grain or berry; M. L. masc. n. Marinococcus marine coccus.)
Cells are spherical, 1.0 to 1.2 μm in diameter, and occur singly, in pairs, tetrads or in clumps.
Motile.
The motile cells usually have one or two flagella.
Nonsporeforming.
Gram positive.
Colonies are circular and smooth, and may be either yellow orange in color or nonpigmented.
Strains grow well in MH medium as well as in nutrient agar with 5 to 20 sodium chloride but not grow in media without salt.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Metabolism respiratory.
Strictly aerobic.
Catalase positive.
Acid may or may not be produced from sugars.
Optimum temperature for growth: 30° to 37°.
The cell wall contains peptidoglycan of meso-diaminopimelic acid type.
Major menaquinone is MK-7.
The DNA base composition ranges from 43.9 to 46.6 %.
Distribution: Sea water, solar saltern, and saline soil.
Type species: Marinococcus halophilus (Novitsky and Kushner 1976) Hao, Kocur, and Komagata comb. nov.
